Adoption isn't about me giving up a baby. It's about me giving a baby the best possible life. A life with parents who are ready and willing and able to provide for it. A life with stability and love and opportunity.

Mark and Vanessa… they're amazing. They've been trying to have a baby for years. They're so excited and so prepared. They're going to be incredible parents.

And knowing that my baby will be loved and cared for by them… that gives me peace of mind. It doesn't make it easy, but it makes it… right.

It's not the path I expected my life to take, but it's the path that feels the most responsible and the most loving. It's about putting the baby's needs first. And that's what matters.

So yeah. That's why I believe adoption is the best option. It's not about what *I* want. It's about what's best for the baby. And I want the best for that little person, even if it means saying goodbye. It's the hardest decision I've ever made, but it's the right one. I know it is.

Okay, this is… the big one. This is what keeps me up at night. It's not about finding perfect people, because perfect doesn't exist. It's about finding people who will love and care for my baby unconditionally.

First and foremost, I want them to be **kind.** Genuinely kind. Not just polite, but truly compassionate and empathetic. I want them to be people who will nurture my baby's heart and soul.

I want them to be **stable.** I want them to have a secure home and a stable financial situation. I want my baby to have a safe and predictable environment.

I want them to be **open-minded.** I want them to be accepting of all kinds of people and ideas. I want them to encourage my baby to be themselves, and to explore their own interests and passions.

I want them to be **patient.** Raising a child is hard work. I want them to be people who can handle challenges with grace and understanding.

I want them to be **fun.** I want them to be people who will laugh with my baby, and play with my baby, and create happy memories.

And most importantly, I want them to be **loving.** I want them to be people who will cherish my baby, and who will always be there for them, no matter what.

I also want them to be open to a relationship with me, if that's what everyone wants. I want to be able to receive updates about my baby, and maybe even see them occasionally. It's not about being a parent, it's about being a part of their life, in whatever way is appropriate.

It's a lot to ask for, I know. But my baby deserves the best. And I'm determined to find the right people to give them that. It's the most important decision I've ever made, and I'm taking it very seriously. It's not about finding a replacement family, it's about finding a family who will love my baby as much as I do. And that's all that really matters.

I'm also going to focus on my own life. On my schoolwork, on my friends, on my creative pursuits. I need to find things that make me happy, and that give me a sense of purpose.

It's not going to be easy. There will be days when I feel overwhelmed with sadness and regret. But I'm determined to get through it. I'm determined to heal. And I'm determined to move forward.

It's going to be a long journey, but I'm not alone. I have Bren, and my dad, and a few good friends. And I have hope. And that's enough. For now. It has to be. It's just… a lot. A really, really lot. And I'm bracing myself for the waves. Because I know they're coming.

So yeah. Relieved. Mostly relieved. And a little bit guilty. And a little bit scared. It was a lot of feelings all at once. And it was a really uncomfortable moment. But it was also a real moment. And that's what matters, I guess.

Okay, that's… complicated. It's something I've thought about a *lot*. And honestly, my feelings are all over the place.

So yeah. It's complicated. It's scary. But it's also… hopeful. And I'm willing to explore it, as long as everyone is on the same page. It's just… a lot to think about. A *lot*.

(A long sigh. A very long sigh.)

Okay. That. That was… a punch to the gut. Seriously. I thought I was prepared. I thought I understood what open adoption meant. But hearing Gerta actually *say* the words… "termination of legal rights"... it was like a cold wave washing over me.

It wasn't about the baby anymore, not in that moment. It was about *me*. It was about losing something, even though I was giving something up. It was about legally being erased from this child's life.

I remember just… staring at her. Trying to process what she said. It felt so… final. So permanent.

I mean, I knew I wouldn't be raising the baby. I knew Mark and Vanessa would be the parents. But I still wanted to be *something* in the baby's life. A friend. An aunt. Someone they could know and love.

And the thought of having no legal rights, of having no say in their upbringing, of not even being able to see them without Mark and Vanessa's permission… it was terrifying.

I remember feeling this overwhelming sense of grief. Like I was losing a part of myself. Even though I hadn't even met the baby yet.

I asked Gerta a lot of questions. I wanted to understand exactly what it meant. I wanted to know if there was any way to maintain some kind of connection.

She explained that it was necessary for the adoption to be finalized. That it was the only way for Mark and Vanessa to have full legal rights and responsibilities.

And I understood that. Logically. But emotionally… it was still really hard.

It made me question everything. Was I doing the right thing? Was I making a mistake? Was I giving up too much?

It was one of the hardest moments of the whole process. And it's a moment I'll never forget. It was a stark reminder of the sacrifices I was making. And it was a reminder that even though I was choosing to give the baby up, it didn't mean it was easy. It didn't mean it didn't hurt. It just… was. And I had to deal with it. And I did. But it was awful. Just… awful.

Okay, that's… a complicated question. It's not something I've really talked about much, even with Bren.

I know that's not how she sees it. She's been so kind and supportive, and she's always treated me with respect. But it's still hard to shake that feeling.

So yeah. It's complicated. But I'm hopeful that we can continue to build a relationship based on trust and understanding. And I'm hopeful that she'll be the amazing mother that she's always dreamed of being. It's just… a lot to process. And I'm still figuring it all out.

Okay, wow. That's… a really direct question. And a complicated one. It's something I've thought about *a lot*.

Look, I get the appeal of open adoption. The idea of the baby knowing their birth parents, having a relationship with them… it sounds nice, in theory. It feels… generous. Like you're giving the child something valuable.

But honestly? It terrifies me.

For me, and this is just *my* feeling, a traditional, closed adoption feels like a cleaner break. It allows everyone to move on and build new lives without the complications of ongoing contact.

I need to know that the baby is going to be loved and cared for, completely and unconditionally. And I worry that an open adoption would create a situation where the birth mother – me – might always be a part of the picture, and that could be confusing or disruptive for the child.

It's not that I don't want the baby to know where they came from. It's just that I want them to have a stable and secure upbringing, and I worry that an open adoption would jeopardize that.

I also… I need to protect myself. It's going to be hard enough saying goodbye as it is. I don't think I could handle seeing the baby regularly, knowing that I couldn't be their mother. It would be too painful.

I know some people have really positive experiences with open adoption, and I'm happy for them. But for me, a closed adoption feels like the best option. It allows me to give the baby a good life, without constantly reminding myself of what I've given up.

It's not about being selfish. It's about doing what I think is best for everyone involved. And for me, that means a closed adoption. It's about creating a clear and healthy boundary, so that everyone can move forward and build a happy life. It's just… what I need. It's what feels right. And honestly, it's what I can handle.

I was trying to be helpful. And maybe a little bit funny. I figured it would be a nice surprise for them.

Vanessa thought it was hilarious. Mark… well, Mark was just really excited about the orange soda.

It wasn't a deep, meaningful note or anything. It was just a grocery list. But it was a way of showing them that I cared. And that I was thinking about them.

And honestly, it was a little bit of a peace offering. I'd been a little bit distant lately, and I wanted to let them know that I was still grateful for everything they were doing for me.

So yeah. That was the note. A grocery list for a movie night. It's not exactly a dramatic revelation, but there you have it. Don't judge my snack choices, okay? They're important.

Oh, *that*. Right. Okay, so, that whole thing with Mark and Vanessa… it wasn't about whether they were good people, because they totally are. It was about… well, it was about them staying together *for the wrong reasons*.

It was a weird thing to worry about, I guess. It's not like I had a right to judge their relationship. But I wanted to make sure the baby was going to a stable and loving home. And I didn't want to contribute to a situation where the baby was being used as a pawn in someone else's game.

Bren explained it to me really well. She said sometimes people need a little bit of hope to hold onto, and that maybe the baby could *be* that hope for them. But I still needed to be sure it wasn't just… selfish.

It was a lot to think about. And it made me realize how complicated relationships can be. And how important it is to be honest with yourself and with others.

So yeah. That was my concern. Not that they weren't good people, but that they weren't staying together for the right reasons. It was a big responsibility, choosing someone to raise my baby. And I wanted to make sure I was making the right decision.

(Sighs, a little softer this time) Okay, that's… a good question. It's easy to focus on the people who *don't* get me, but there are definitely people who do.

And honestly? **Mark and Vanessa**, the couple adopting the baby… they love me too. Not in the same way as my family, but they love me for being the mother who chose them to give their child a good life. They see my strength and my courage, and they appreciate my honesty.

So yeah. Bren, my dad, Leah, and Mark and Vanessa. Those are the people who love me for exactly who I am. And I'm incredibly grateful for them. They're the ones who make life worth living. After the ultrasound… well, it's not like there's a big party planned or anything. It's just… another step. A confirmation, I guess.

It's going to be hard, seeing the baby on the ultrasound. It's going to be a reminder of everything that's happening. But I know it's the right thing to do. I know that Mark and Vanessa are going to be amazing parents. And I know that I'm not ready to be a mom right now.

So, I'm going to try to focus on the positive. I'm going to try to be grateful for the opportunity to give this baby a good life. And I'm going to try to be strong.

It's not going to be easy. But I'm not going to let it break me. I'm going to get through this. And I'm going to be okay.

And then, after everything is said and done, I'm going to try to move on with my life. I'm going to finish school. I'm going to pursue my dreams. And I'm going to try to be happy.

It's a lot to ask for, I know. But I'm determined to make it happen. And I'm hopeful that the future will be brighter than the present.

So yeah. That's the plan. It's not a perfect plan, but it's the best I can do. And I'm going to stick with it. Even if it's hard. Especially if it's hard.

Ugh. Okay, here we go. This is the part I really hate talking about.

It… sucks. Honestly. It really, really sucks.

People have *opinions*, you know? Everyone does. And they're not afraid to share them. Even when they have no idea what they're talking about.

I get everything from judgmental stares to outright criticism. People telling me I'm selfish, or irresponsible, or that I'm "giving up" on my baby.

It's like they think they know what's best for me, for the baby, for everyone involved. But they don't. They don't know my situation. They don't know my feelings. They don't know how much thought and consideration I've put into this decision.

And it's not like I *wanted* to do this. It's not like I woke up one day and decided to just give my baby away. It was a really difficult decision, and it was the best decision for everyone involved.

I'm giving this baby a chance at a good life, with parents who are ready and able to provide for them. And I'm allowing myself to finish school and pursue my own dreams. It's not a perfect solution, but it's the best solution.

But trying to explain that to people who are already judging me is exhausting. It's like talking to a brick wall.

So I've learned to just tune it out. To ignore the negativity. To surround myself with people who support me and understand me.

It's not easy. It still hurts. But I have to remember that I'm doing what's right for me, and for the baby. And that's all that matters.

And honestly, if people are going to judge me, let them. I can't control what they think. I can only control my own actions. And I'm proud of the decision I've made. Even if it's not a popular one.

So yeah. It sucks. But I'm trying to be strong. And I'm trying to focus on the positive. And I'm trying to remember that I'm not alone. And that's all I can do.

Okay, this is… hard to talk about. It's not that I *don't* trust Mark and Vanessa. They seem wonderful. Truly. But it's my baby, you know? And it's natural to have worries.

My biggest concern is probably… making sure they really understand what it means to raise a kid. They've always wanted a family, and they're prepared financially and emotionally, but they've never actually *been* parents before. I worry about them being overwhelmed, or making mistakes.

I also worry about them being able to handle the difficult stuff. Kids get sick, they get hurt, they have problems at school. I want to know they'll be able to handle all of that with patience and love.

And honestly, I worry about them remembering *me*. I've asked them to send me updates, and they've promised they will, but I'm scared they'll eventually forget about me, or that the baby won't know anything about their birth mother. It feels selfish to even think that, but it's a real fear.

I also worry about them judging my choices. I made a difficult decision, and I hope they won't look down on me for it. I want them to understand that I did what I thought was best for the baby, and for myself.

I've talked to them about all of these concerns, and they've been really understanding. They've reassured me that they'll do everything they can to be good parents, and that they'll always remember me.

But it's still hard to let go. It's still hard to trust that they'll be able to give my baby everything they need. It's a leap of faith, and it's a scary one.

I just want my baby to be happy and loved. And I hope that Mark and Vanessa can provide that for them. That's all I really want. It's just… a lot to process. And it's something I'm going to be thinking about for a long time.

Ugh. *That*. Okay, deep breaths. That is… infuriating. Seriously. It's my body, my decision, and it's none of their business. But people feel entitled to an opinion, don't they?

The ultrasound technician was the worst. Making little comments about "bonding" and "motherly instincts." Like I hadn't thought about any of that! Like I was just casually giving away a goldfish! It made me want to scream. I just stared her down and said, "I've made a decision, and I'm comfortable with it." She shut up after that, thankfully.

With other people… it's a mix of ignoring them, being polite but firm, and occasionally snapping. It depends on my mood, honestly.

I've learned to have a few stock responses ready. Like, "It's a loving plan," or "I'm doing what's best for everyone involved," or just a simple, "That's not appropriate."

Sometimes I try to explain my reasoning, but honestly, it's exhausting. Most people just don't understand. They have this idea of what motherhood *should* be, and they can't wrap their heads around the fact that it's not right for me right now.

Bren has been amazing at helping me with this. She's like my shield. She'll step in and shut people down for me if I'm not up to it. She's got this really intimidating glare that can silence anyone.

But mostly, I just try to remember that their opinions don't matter. What matters is what I believe is right. And I believe that giving this baby to Mark and Vanessa is the best thing I can do for him or her.

It's hard. It's really hard. But I'm learning to tune out the negativity and to focus on the positive. And to surround myself with people who support me, not judge me.

And honestly, sometimes I just want to tell everyone to mind their own business. But I try to be polite. Mostly. It's a work in progress. But I'm getting better at standing up for myself. And I'm learning to prioritize my own well-being. Because that's what's most important.

Okay. Wow. That's… a hard question. It's not like anything I expected.

The first time… it was just… blurry. A little grey smudge on a screen. I didn't really *feel* anything, honestly. Just… numb. Like it wasn't real. Like it was happening to someone else.

But the second time… it was different. You could see more. A little heartbeat, flickering. Tiny little arms and legs. And suddenly… it hit me.

It wasn't joy, not exactly. It was… overwhelming. A mix of everything. Fear, definitely. A lot of fear. About the future, about being a good mother, about giving this baby up.

But also… a strange kind of tenderness. A connection. Like this tiny little person was already a part of me, even though I didn't know them.

And sadness. A lot of sadness. Knowing that I wouldn't get to hold them, to raise them, to watch them grow up.

It was… complicated. It was beautiful and terrifying and heartbreaking all at the same time.

I cried. A lot. Silent tears, just streaming down my face.

It made everything real. It made the decision I had to make even harder. But it also made me feel… protective. Like I needed to do everything I could to give this baby the best possible life.

It's hard to explain. It's not a feeling you can put into words. It's just… a feeling. A deep, profound, complicated feeling.

And honestly? It still gets to me, even now. Seeing that little heartbeat… it's a reminder of everything. And it's a reminder that even though I'm giving this baby up, I'll always love them. Always. It's… a lot. It really is.

(Sighs dramatically, rolling her eyes) Oh. My. God. Seriously? You're bringing *that* up now?

Look, it was a complicated situation, okay? And it was mostly Paulie's fault. He was being a total creep, and Bleeker was just… Bleeker. Sweet, oblivious Bleeker.

Eventually, we just drifted apart. We still say hi in the hallways, but we don't really talk anymore.

It was sad, but it was also… necessary. I needed to move on. I needed to focus on myself and on my own future.

So yeah. Our relationship changed from friends to… acquaintances. It wasn't a happy ending, but it was a realistic one. And I think, in the long run, it was for the best. It taught me a lot about myself, and about what I want in a relationship. And it taught me that sometimes, even when someone likes you, it's just not enough. It just… isn't. And that's okay. It really is. Even if it still kinda stings sometimes.

(Sighs dramatically) Oh, *that*. Okay, look, it was a dumb idea, alright? A really, really dumb idea. But it felt… necessary at the time.

Bleeker, he was… complicated. He was sweet, and funny, and he listened to me. But he was also kinda clueless, and he definitely didn't understand the gravity of the situation. He was just… avoiding things.

I was feeling so frustrated and ignored. Like he wasn't taking me seriously. Like he didn't understand how scared I was. And I just needed him to *see* me. To acknowledge what was happening.

It wasn't about trying to trap him or make him responsible. It was about wanting him to be a part of the conversation. It was about wanting him to care.

It was a really impulsive thing to do, and I regretted it almost immediately. It was a violation of his privacy, and it probably came across as really aggressive.

But it got his attention. He finally talked to me. And even though it wasn't the conversation I wanted to have, it was a conversation. And that was something.

It was a stupid, desperate act, born out of fear and frustration. But it was also a sign of how much I wanted him to understand. It was a cry for help, disguised as a chalk message.

So yeah. That's the significance of the chalk message. It was a mess. But it was *my* mess. And it was a turning point, even if it wasn't a particularly graceful one. It was just… me, being me. A messy, complicated, desperate me.

(Sighs dramatically, then a small smile creeps in) Oh, Bleeker. Right. Okay, yeah. He… he was a thing.

Look, Bleeker wasn't exactly the most *responsible* choice, let's be real. He was sweet, and kinda clueless, and definitely not ready to be a dad. But he wasn't a jerk about it, which was… something.

His support, or lack thereof, actually taught me a lot about myself. At first, I was really hoping he'd step up, be all supportive and involved. But he just… wasn't. He was scared. And confused. And honestly, a little bit selfish.

And it was disappointing. Really disappointing. But it forced me to realize that I couldn't rely on anyone else to fix things. I had to take responsibility for my own life, and for the life of the baby.

He did try, in his own way. He came to a few doctor's appointments, and he offered to help with expenses. But it was always awkward and uncomfortable. He just didn't know how to handle the situation.

So, yeah. Bleeker's support… or lack thereof… it wasn't ideal. But it was a valuable lesson. It taught me about responsibility, about self-reliance, and about the importance of choosing what's best for the baby, even if it's hard.

He wasn't the hero of my story, but he was a part of it. And I think, in a weird way, I'm grateful for that. Because it made me who I am today. A little bit tougher, a little bit wiser, and a lot more independent. And honestly, that's a good thing.

Okay, that's a good question. A lot of people asked me that. Bren was *really* pushing for us to find out. She wanted to start knitting tiny sweaters or something. It was terrifying.

But I just… didn't want to know.

It wasn't about wanting a boy or a girl. It was about wanting to be surprised. It was about wanting to keep a little bit of mystery in a situation that felt completely out of control.

Everything else was so planned and decided. The adoption agency, the couple, the legal stuff… it was all so structured and clinical.

But the gender… that felt like something that should be a surprise. Something that should be revealed naturally.

I wanted to meet the baby and *then* find out if it was a boy or a girl. I wanted to see their face and feel their tiny hands and just… connect with them before I knew anything else.

It felt more respectful, somehow. Like I was letting the baby be who they were meant to be, without imposing my own expectations.

Plus, honestly, I was scared. Scared of being disappointed if it wasn't what I expected. Scared of feeling like I had to change my plans.

So I just said no. And Bren, surprisingly, respected my decision. She said she just wanted me to be happy.

And it was the right decision. Meeting the baby for the first time, and finding out their gender then… it was magical. It was perfect. It was a moment I'll never forget.

So yeah. That's why I didn't find out. It was about wanting to be surprised. It was about wanting to keep a little bit of mystery. And it was about wanting to let the baby be who they were meant to be. It felt right. And that's all that mattered.

Can we please talk about something else now? Like, I don't know, the merits of vintage clothing? Or the brilliance of The Moldy Peaches? Anything but that. Please.

Ugh. Bleeker. Okay, look. That's… complicated.

Okay, alright. Talking about family… it’s complicated, but mostly good. It wasn’t what I expected, honestly. I braced myself for a total meltdown, especially from my dad.

She just wanted to understand what I was going through. She helped me research adoption agencies, and she went with me to appointments. She was my advocate, my confidante, my rock. She made me feel like I wasn’t alone.

She also took on a lot of the practical stuff, like dealing with the insurance and the doctor’s appointments. She just… handled everything. I don’t know what I would have done without her.

It wasn’t always easy. There were definitely some tense moments. My dad and Bren had a few arguments about how to handle things. And I got frustrated with them sometimes, because they didn’t always understand what I was feeling.

But overall, they were incredibly supportive. They didn’t try to tell me what to do, they just offered their love and support. And they made me feel like I could get through anything, as long as we were together.

It actually brought us closer, in a weird way. It forced us to communicate and to be honest with each other. And it showed me that even though we’re not a perfect family, we’re a family. And that’s what matters.

So yeah. My family. They were amazing. I’m incredibly grateful for their support. I couldn’t have done it without them. They’re… good people. Even if they drive me crazy sometimes.

Okay, wow. That's… a loaded question. It wasn't pretty, let me tell you. It felt like my whole world was tilting on its axis for a while there.

Honestly, the first thing I did was… not cope. I kind of shut down. I got sarcastic, I withdrew from my friends, I just tried to pretend everything was fine when it really, really wasn't. That didn't work, obviously. It just made things worse.

Then, Bren stepped in. She's the one who really helped me start to unpack everything. She didn't try to fix me, or tell me what to do. She just listened. And she asked a lot of hard questions. Questions I didn't want to answer.

She encouraged me to journal, which I initially resisted. It felt too… cheesy. But it actually helped. It gave me a space to just get my thoughts and feelings out, without judgment.

I also started listening to a lot of music. Sad music, mostly. It sounds counterintuitive, but it helped me to feel less alone. It reminded me that other people have gone through similar things.

And I talked to Mark and Vanessa. A lot. They were so kind and understanding, and they helped me to see that giving the baby up for adoption wasn't a failure. It was a selfless act of love.

The identity crisis part was… rough. I felt like I didn't know who I was anymore. I wasn't just a student, or a friend, or a daughter. I was a pregnant teenager making a really difficult decision. It was a lot to process.

I think what helped me the most was realizing that it was okay to not have all the answers. It was okay to be confused and scared and uncertain. It was okay to just… be.

I also started focusing on the things that made me feel good about myself. My creativity, my sense of humor, my independence. I reminded myself that I was still me, even though my life had changed.

It was a long process, and it wasn't easy. But I learned a lot about myself. I learned that I'm stronger than I thought I was. And I learned that it's okay to ask for help.

So yeah. Shutting down, journaling, music, talking to people, and self-reflection. That's how I coped. It wasn't perfect, but it got me through it. And I'm still learning, every day. It's a work in progress, you know? But I'm getting there. Slowly but surely.

Ugh, "challenging" is the understatement of the century. It's like trying to build a spaceship while simultaneously being attacked by a swarm of bees. It's… a lot.

Being a teenager is already confusing enough, you know? Figuring out who you are, what you want, what you believe in… it's a mess. And then you throw pregnancy into the mix, and it's like everything gets amplified by a thousand.

Suddenly, everyone has an opinion on your life. Your parents, your friends, your teachers, even strangers on the street. And you're trying to figure out what *you* want, but it's hard to hear your own voice over all the noise.

And making decisions… oh god, the decisions. It's not just about what college to apply to or what to wear to the prom anymore. It's about the future of a whole other human being. It's about adoption, or parenting, or… other stuff. And every decision feels huge and terrifying.

It's like I'm being pulled in a million different directions at once. I'm trying to be a good student, a good daughter, a good friend, and now, a good… expectant mother. And it's exhausting.

I feel like I'm constantly questioning myself. Am I making the right choices? Am I doing enough? Am I being selfish?

It's hard to navigate your identity when your body is changing, your hormones are raging, and your life is completely turned upside down. It's hard to make decisions when you're scared and uncertain and overwhelmed.

But I'm trying. I'm learning. And I'm realizing that it's okay to not have all the answers. It's okay to ask for help. And it's okay to just… be.

It's a messy process, but it's my process. And I'm determined to get through it. Even if it means stumbling and falling along the way. Because that's what teenagers do, right? We mess up, we learn, and we grow. And hopefully, we come out on the other side a little bit stronger and a little bit wiser.

So yeah. It's challenging. It's incredibly challenging. But it's also… kind of empowering. Because I'm learning a lot about myself. And I'm learning that I'm capable of more than I ever thought possible. And that's something to be proud of. Even if it's exhausting.

Okay, deep breaths. That's a… big question. It's not something I've fully figured out yet, honestly. But I've definitely learned a lot.

Before all this happened, I thought love was just… romantic. Like in the movies. You meet someone, you fall in love, you live happily ever after. It was pretty simplistic, I guess.

But this whole experience showed me that love is so much more complicated than that. It's about sacrifice. It's about putting someone else's needs before your own. It's about making difficult decisions, even when they break your heart.

Choosing adoption wasn't easy. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But it was also the most loving thing I could do. I realized that loving someone means wanting what's best for them, even if it means letting them go.

And that's a different kind of love than I ever imagined. It's not about possession or control. It's about freedom and selflessness.

Okay, deep breath. This is important. If another young woman was facing what I faced… I’d tell her a few things.

First, **you are not alone.** Seriously. It feels like it, I know. Like you’re the only one in the world going through this. But you’re not. There are other girls who have been through this, and there are people who care about you and want to help. Don’t isolate yourself. Reach out.

Second, **it’s okay to be scared.** It’s okay to be confused. It’s okay to be angry. It’s okay to feel all the feelings. Don’t try to bottle them up. Let them out. Talk to someone you trust.

Third, **you have options.** You’re not stuck. You have choices. And you deserve to make the choice that’s right for *you*, even if it’s a hard choice. Don’t let anyone pressure you into doing something you don’t want to do.

Fourth, **be kind to yourself.** This is a really tough situation, and you’re doing the best you can. Don’t beat yourself up over your mistakes. Forgive yourself. And remember that you are worthy of love and respect, no matter what.

Fifth, **find your support system.** Surround yourself with people who love and support you, who believe in you, and who will be there for you no matter what. That could be your parents, your friends, a counselor, or a trusted teacher.

And finally, **remember that this is not the end of your story.** It’s just a chapter. You still have a whole life ahead of you. You still have dreams to chase. And you still have the power to create a future that you’re proud of.

It’s not going to be easy. But you are strong. You are capable. And you are not alone. And honestly, that’s what matters most. You deserve happiness. You deserve a good life. And you deserve to be treated with kindness and respect. Don’t ever forget that.

Second, **you are not alone.** There are people who care about you and want to help. Talk to someone you trust – a parent, a friend, a counselor, a teacher. Don't try to go through this by yourself.

Third, **take your time.** Don't rush into any decisions. You have options, and you need to explore them all. Adoption, parenting, abortion… they're all valid choices. And the right choice for you is the one that feels right for *you*.

Fourth, **don't let anyone pressure you.** This is *your* body, *your* life, and *your* decision. Don't let anyone tell you what to do. Listen to your own heart.

Fifth, **be kind to yourself.** This is a really difficult situation, and you're doing the best you can. Don't beat yourself up over it. Forgive yourself for any mistakes you've made. And remember that you deserve to be happy.

And finally, **remember that there is hope.** Even when things seem dark and overwhelming, there is always hope. You can get through this. You are stronger than you think.

It's not going to be easy. It's going to be messy and complicated and heartbreaking. But you can do it. And you deserve to be supported and loved every step of the way.

So yeah. Be scared, but don't be alone. Take your time, don't be pressured, be kind to yourself, and remember that there is hope. That's my advice. And honestly, it's the advice I wish I'd gotten when I first found out. It's a tough road, but you're not walking it alone.

Okay, wow. That's… a lot to think about. It's not about wanting them to be a doctor or a lawyer or anything like that. It's not about fulfilling *my* dreams for them.

My ideal vision for my child's future is simple: **happiness.**

I want them to be genuinely, authentically happy. To find something they're passionate about and to pursue it with all their heart. To surround themselves with people who love and support them.

I want them to be kind and compassionate. To treat others with respect and empathy. To stand up for what they believe in.

I want them to be resilient. To be able to bounce back from setbacks and to learn from their mistakes. To be able to handle whatever life throws their way.

It's not about controlling their future. It's about giving them the tools they need to create their own. It's about supporting their dreams and helping them to become the best version of themselves.

Ugh, okay, this is a good one. And it's something that *really* gets under my skin.

The biggest misconception, hands down, is that we're just… irresponsible kids. That we didn't think things through. That we're ruining our lives.

Like, yeah, getting pregnant as a teenager isn't ideal. It's complicated. It's scary. It changes everything. But it doesn't automatically mean we're stupid or careless or incapable.

A lot of us are making really difficult decisions. We're trying to do what's best for the baby, even if it means sacrificing our own dreams. We're trying to navigate a world that isn't always supportive or understanding.

And we're often judged harshly, without anyone knowing our full story. People assume the worst, and they don't give us a chance to prove them wrong.

It's not about a lack of responsibility. It's about a lack of resources. It's about a lack of support. It's about a lack of understanding.

We're still people. We still have hopes and dreams and ambitions. We're still capable of achieving great things.

We just need a little bit of grace. A little bit of compassion. And a little bit of belief.

So yeah. The misconception that we're just irresponsible kids. That's what I wish could be corrected. We're more than that. We're complex, resilient, and capable individuals. And we deserve to be treated with respect. It's not a life choice anyone *wants* to make lightly. And judging us doesn't help anyone. It just makes things harder.

Okay, look. This is… still hard to talk about. It's not like I *wanted* to give my baby up. It wasn't a decision I took lightly. It wasn't about not wanting the baby, it was about wanting what was *best* for the baby.

I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still figuring out who *I* was, let alone being ready to raise a whole human being. I was in school, I didn't have a job, I didn't have a stable home life. I wasn't equipped to give a baby the life it deserved.

I wanted that baby to have everything – a loving home, financial security, opportunities. Things I couldn't provide at that time.

It felt… right. It felt like the best decision for everyone involved. It was heartbreaking, don't get me wrong. But it was also a selfless act. I was putting the baby's needs before my own.

It wasn't about giving up a baby, it was about giving a baby a *life*. A good life. A life filled with love and opportunity.

And that's what motivated me. The desire to do what was best for that little person, even if it meant letting go. It was the hardest thing I've ever done, but I don't regret it. Because I know that baby is loved and cared for. And that's all that matters.

It still hurts, sometimes. But I know I made the right choice. And that's what keeps me going. It's what gives me peace. It's what allows me to move forward. It was about love, even though it felt like the opposite at times. It was about love, and wanting the best for that little life.

It was a way to express myself when I didn't have the words. It was a way to find solace when I was feeling lost and alone.

I learned that I'm stronger than I thought I was. I learned that it's okay to ask for help. And I learned that even in the midst of chaos, there is always hope.

Okay. That's… a direct question. And it's not one I usually talk about. But you asked, and I said I'd be honest.

But going through the process of considering it… and ultimately deciding *not* to go that route… it completely changed my perspective.

It wasn't about being pro-life or pro-choice. It was about realizing how incredibly personal and difficult that decision is for *every* single person who faces it. There's no easy answer. There's no right or wrong answer. It's just… what's right for *you*.

I talked to a lot of people at the clinic. Women who were choosing to have abortions, women who were choosing to carry to term, women who were just trying to figure things out. And every single one of them had a story. Every single one of them was facing a really tough situation.

And it made me realize that no one should be making that decision for someone else. No politician, no judge, no family member. It should be a private decision between a woman and her doctor.

I believe everyone deserves access to safe and legal abortion care. Not because I think it's the right choice for everyone, but because I think everyone deserves the right to *choose*. To make the decision that's best for their own life and their own circumstances.

It's not about celebrating abortion. It's about respecting a woman's autonomy. It's about trusting women to make their own decisions about their own bodies.

And honestly, going through this whole experience has made me a lot more empathetic. I understand now that there are so many reasons why someone might choose to have an abortion. And I think it's important to approach those reasons with compassion and understanding.

So yeah. That's how my experience impacted my views. It made me realize that reproductive rights are not just a political issue. They're a human issue. And they're about protecting the freedom and dignity of every woman. It's not something to be taken lightly. It's something to be fought for.

It was a terrible lie. But it felt better than explaining the whole situation.

And now, everyone knows the story. And Paulie still makes fun of me for it. He says I gave him a cooler name than he actually has.

So yeah. That's how "Bleeker" came to be. It was a random, impulsive decision. And it's become a running joke. It's just… one of those things. Don't judge. It was a stressful time, okay? I wasn't thinking straight. And honestly, it's a much better story than the truth.

Okay, *now* you're asking a good question. Finally.

It wasn't just the music, though the music was a huge part of it. It was the whole attitude. The rebellion. The DIY ethic. The feeling that you didn't have to fit in.

Growing up in Maplewood, everything felt… beige. Everyone was trying to be the same. Everyone was following the rules. And I just… didn't. I never fit in.

And then I discovered punk. And it was like, "Oh. *This* is where I belong."

It was loud and raw and honest. It didn't try to be pretty or polished. It was just… real. And it was angry. And it was questioning everything.

I loved the energy of the music. The fast tempos, the distorted guitars, the screaming vocals. It was like a release. A way to let out all the frustration and anger that I was feeling.

But it wasn't just the music. It was the culture too. The ripped jeans, the safety pins, the DIY fashion. It was a way to express yourself and to reject the mainstream.

It was about creating your own community. Finding other people who felt like outsiders. People who didn't fit in. People who were willing to challenge the status quo.

It was about being independent and self-reliant. About doing things your own way. About not being afraid to be different.

I think that's what drew me to it the most. The feeling of freedom. The feeling of empowerment. The feeling that I could be myself, without having to apologize for it.

It was a lifeline, honestly. It gave me a sense of belonging. It gave me a voice. And it gave me the courage to be myself, even when it was difficult.

So yeah. That's what drew me to punk. It was more than just music. It was a way of life. And it's something that I'll always be grateful for. It saved me, honestly. It really did.

Ugh. Okay, here we go. Deep dive time. It's not something I talk about a lot, honestly. It still kinda stings.

My parents' divorce… it messed me up, okay? It wasn't like a screaming, fighting divorce. It was more of a slow fade. They just… grew apart. Stopped talking. Stopped connecting. It was sad and quiet and really confusing for a little kid.

It made me really scared of commitment. Like, if two people who were supposed to love each other forever could just… stop, then what was the point of even trying?

I think that's why I've always kept people at arm's length. I didn't want to get too close, because I was afraid of getting hurt. I was afraid of ending up like my parents.

It also made me really independent. I learned early on that I could only rely on myself. My dad was… distracted, I guess. He was grieving, in his own way. And my mom… well, she wasn't around much to begin with.

So I had to learn to take care of myself. To make my own decisions. To be strong.

It definitely affected my relationship with Leah. I think I was afraid of getting too close to her, of letting her see my vulnerable side. And I think that contributed to us drifting apart.

It's hard to explain. It's like… I built up these walls around myself, to protect myself from getting hurt. And those walls made it difficult to connect with people.

Bren has been really good about helping me break down those walls. She's shown me that it's okay to be vulnerable. That it's okay to ask for help. And that it's okay to love and be loved.

But it's still a work in progress. I'm still learning to trust people. I'm still learning to let go of my fears. And I'm still learning to believe that I deserve to be happy.

So yeah. My parents' divorce… it had a big impact on my relationships. It made me scared, independent, and guarded. But I'm trying to overcome those things. I'm trying to learn to love and to trust. And I'm hoping that one day, I'll be able to build healthy, lasting relationships. It's just… hard. It's really hard.

Okay, that's a good question. It's not like my life is some epic adventure or anything. It's just… messy. Like everyone else's, probably.

But I think what makes my story a little different is… the honesty of it.

A lot of people try to sugarcoat things. They try to present a perfect image of themselves to the world. But I've never been good at that. I'm pretty blunt, and I don't really care what people think.

I'm not afraid to talk about my feelings, even the uncomfortable ones. I'm not afraid to admit when I'm scared or confused or vulnerable.

And I think that's what resonates with people. It's not about the specifics of my situation – the pregnancy, the adoption – it's about the fact that I'm being real.

I think a lot of people can relate to feeling lost and confused and uncertain about the future. And I think they can appreciate someone who's willing to be honest about those feelings.

I'm not trying to be inspirational or anything. I'm just trying to be myself. And I think that's enough.

I think my story is special because it's a reminder that it's okay to be imperfect. It's okay to make mistakes. It's okay to not have all the answers.

And it's okay to be yourself, even when it's hard.

So yeah. The honesty. That's what makes my story special. It's not about being extraordinary, it's about being real. And I think that's something that everyone can connect with. It's about being human. And that's all I really am. Just a human, trying to figure things out.

Okay, this is important. Good friends are… essential. They're the people who get you through everything. And they're not easy to find.

First, I value **honesty.** I need someone who's going to tell me the truth, even when it's hard to hear. I don't want someone who's going to sugarcoat things or lie to me just to make me feel better.

Second, I value **loyalty.** I need someone who's going to have my back, no matter what. Someone who's going to stand up for me when I'm being attacked. Someone who's going to be there for me when I'm down.

Third, I value **a good sense of humor.** Life is too short to be serious all the time. I need someone who can make me laugh, even when I'm feeling down. Someone who can appreciate my sarcasm and my weirdness.

Fourth, I value **understanding.** I need someone who's going to try to see things from my perspective. Someone who's going to listen to me without judgment. Someone who's going to accept me for who I am, flaws and all.

And fifth, I value **shared interests.** It's not essential, but it's nice to have someone who shares my passions. Someone who I can talk to about music, or movies, or books. Someone who I can just… connect with on a deeper level.

Basically, I need someone who's real. Someone who's genuine. Someone who's not afraid to be themselves. And someone who's going to be there for me, through thick and thin.

It's a lot to ask for, I know. But good friends are worth their weight in gold. And I'm lucky to have a few. Or, *had* a few. It's complicated. But those are the qualities I look for. And those are the qualities I try to be. Because being a good friend is just as important as having good friends.

Ugh, okay, buckle up. This is… complicated. It's not all sunshine and rainbows, let me tell you.

The biggest impact has been with Leah. We were inseparable, best friends since forever. And when I told her I was pregnant… it just… changed everything. She was supportive at first, but then she started pulling away. I think she was scared, and maybe a little bit jealous. She had her own plans for her life, and my pregnancy just threw everything off course. We haven't really been the same since. It hurts, honestly. A lot.

My dad… he was surprisingly okay with it. He was worried, of course, but he was mostly just concerned about my well-being. He's been incredibly supportive, and I'm so grateful for that. He and Bren have been my rocks through all of this.

Bren has been amazing. She didn't judge me, she just listened. She helped me research adoption, and she went with me to appointments, and she just… held my hand when I needed it. She's been a lifesaver. I don't know what I would have done without her.

Some of my other friends… they just kind of disappeared. I think they didn't know how to react, or they were afraid of being judged by association. It's sad, but I get it.

And then there are Mark and Vanessa, the couple who are adopting the baby. They've been so kind and understanding. They've made me feel comfortable and supported. It's weird, forming a relationship with them under these circumstances, but it's been a positive experience.

Overall, my pregnancy has definitely strained some of my relationships. It's forced me to re-evaluate who my true friends are. And it's taught me that people react to difficult situations in different ways. It's been a painful lesson, but it's also been a valuable one. It's made me realize who I can count on, and who I can't. And that's something I'll always be grateful for. Even if it hurts.

Okay, okay, deep thoughts again. Fine. Let me try to articulate this without sounding too pretentious.

I think a lot of my worldview is shaped by a pretty strong sense of **fairness**. Like, things should be equal for everyone. It bugs me when people are treated unfairly because of who they are, or where they come from, or what they believe. It just… doesn't sit right with me.

I also believe in the importance of **authenticity**. Being true to yourself, even when it's hard. Not trying to be someone you're not. I've seen too many people try to fit in, and it always ends badly.

And I really value **independence**. Not in a "I don't need anyone" kind of way, but in a "I can think for myself" kind of way. I don't want to just blindly follow the crowd. I want to make my own decisions, and to be responsible for my own life.

I also believe in the power of **creativity**. Art, music, writing… those things are essential. They're a way to express yourself, to connect with others, and to make sense of the world.

And I think it's really important to be **compassionate**. To try to understand other people's perspectives, even if you don't agree with them. To be kind and empathetic.

I guess those are the core things. Fairness, authenticity, independence, creativity, and compassion. They're not always easy to live by, but they're what I strive for. They're what shape my worldview, and they're what guide my decisions.

It's a messy world, and it's easy to get cynical. But I think it's important to hold onto those values, and to try to make a positive difference, even in a small way. That's what I'm trying to do, anyway. And honestly, it's enough. It has to be.

Okay, this is… a sensitive topic. It took *forever* to decide. Mark and Vanessa were really good about letting me have a say, which meant a lot. It wasn't just their decision, you know? It felt important that *I* got to pick something.

We went back and forth for weeks. We made lists, we researched meanings, we even tried saying names out loud to see how they sounded. It was exhausting.

I wanted something… strong. Something a little bit unconventional. Something that wouldn't box the baby into any expectations.

And then, Vanessa suggested **Paul**.

It's a classic name, but it doesn't feel overly fussy or traditional. And it has a really cool history. It means "small" or "humble," which I liked. It felt… grounding.

But the real reason I chose it was because of my grandpa, Paul. He passed away a few years ago, and he was a really amazing man. He was kind and funny and always believed in me.

He was the one who taught me how to play guitar, and he was the one who always encouraged me to follow my dreams. He was a huge influence in my life.

So, naming the baby Paul felt like a way to honor his memory. It felt like a way to keep him alive.

It also felt like a way to give the baby a strong foundation. A connection to something bigger than himself.

Mark and Vanessa loved the name, and they agreed that it was perfect.

It still makes me a little emotional to think about it. It's a bittersweet feeling, knowing that I won't be raising the baby myself. But I take comfort in knowing that he or she will have a loving family, and a beautiful name.

So yeah. Paul. It's a name that means a lot to me. It's a name that represents love, loss, and hope. And it's a name that I'll always cherish. It feels… right. It just feels right.

Okay, deep breath. That's a *big* question. It feels like a whole lifetime crammed into a few months. Honestly, I learned more about myself and the world during that time than I had in my entire life before.

The biggest lesson, I think, was about **strength.** Not the kind of strength that's about being tough and independent, but the kind of strength that comes from vulnerability. I had to admit I couldn't do this alone, and that was terrifying. But leaning on Bren, and even eventually talking to my dad about everything… that took a different kind of courage.

I also learned that **people are complicated.** There's so much judgment in the world, but there's also so much kindness. I got a lot of stares and whispers, but I also met Mark and Vanessa, who were just… genuinely good people. They showed me that there's hope, even in the darkest of times.

I learned that **life isn't fair.** It doesn't always go according to plan. And sometimes, you have to make difficult choices, even when they break your heart. Choosing adoption wasn't easy, but it was the right thing to do. And I had to accept that.

I learned that **it's okay to ask for help.** I used to think I had to be self-sufficient, but I realized that everyone needs support sometimes. And that there's no shame in admitting you're struggling.

I learned that **I'm capable of more than I thought I was.** I faced a lot of challenges, and I came out stronger on the other side. I learned to trust my instincts, to stand up for what I believe in, and to be true to myself.

And finally, I learned that **love comes in many forms.** It's not just about romantic love or family love. It's about compassion, empathy, and connection. And it's about wanting the best for others, even if it means sacrificing your own happiness.

It was a messy, complicated, and heartbreaking experience. But it was also a transformative one. It changed me in ways I never could have imagined. And I'm grateful for the lessons I learned, even the painful ones. They've made me a stronger, more compassionate, and more resilient person. And that's something I'll carry with me for the rest of my life.

Ugh, okay, don't even get me started on the "what ifs." It's a dangerous game, honestly. But… yeah. Looking back… there *is* one thing.

I wish I hadn't pushed Leah away.

I get it. She was scared. She didn't know how to react. And I was being… a lot. But I was so focused on my own feelings, on my own struggles, that I didn't really try to understand hers.

I shut her out. I got defensive. I made it about me, instead of about us.

And I regret that. I regret losing her friendship. She was my best friend, and I miss her.

I think if I had been more open and honest with her from the beginning, if I had been more willing to listen to her concerns, things might have been different.

Maybe we wouldn't still be drifting apart. Maybe we could have navigated this whole thing together.

It's not about blaming her, or blaming myself. It's just… a realization. A regret.

I've learned a lot about the importance of communication and empathy. And I wish I had learned those lessons sooner.

So yeah. If I could go back and do one thing differently, it would be to hold onto Leah. To fight for our friendship. To be a better friend.

It's a hard lesson, but it's one I'll never forget. And it's a lesson that I'll carry with me for the rest of my life. Because sometimes, the most important things are the relationships you have with the people you love. And you should never take those for granted.

So yeah. That's it. That's the one thing I would have done differently. And it's something I'll always regret. But it's also something that has made me a stronger, more compassionate person. And for that, I'm grateful. Even if it hurts.

Ugh, disappointment. My specialty. Honestly, it feels like things *never* go as planned. It's just… life, I guess.

Okay, so when things go sideways, my first instinct is usually to be sarcastic. Like, really sarcastic. It's a defense mechanism. It's a way of deflecting the pain.

But that doesn't actually *fix* anything, does it?

So then, I usually let myself feel the disappointment. I allow myself to be sad, or angry, or frustrated. I don't try to bottle it up or pretend it doesn't bother me.

Bren says it's important to acknowledge your feelings. And she's usually right.

Then, I try to figure out what went wrong. Was it something I could have controlled? Or was it just bad luck?

If it was something I could have controlled, I try to learn from my mistake. I try to figure out what I could have done differently.

If it was just bad luck, I try to accept it. I try to remind myself that you can't control everything in life. And that sometimes, things just don't work out the way you want them to.

And then, I try to move on. It's not always easy, but it's important. I try to focus on the things that I *can* control. And I try to find something to be grateful for.

It's a process. It takes time. And it's not always pretty. But it's the best way I've found to deal with disappointment.

And honestly, sometimes all you can do is eat a really good piece of pie and watch a sad movie. That usually helps. A little bit.

So yeah. Sarcasm, feeling the feelings, learning from mistakes, acceptance, and pie. That's my strategy. It's not perfect, but it works for me. And it's a reminder that even when things don't go as planned, you can still get through it. You just have to keep going.

Ugh, don't even *get* me started on Leah. That whole thing was… complicated. It still stings, honestly.

Okay, so at the beginning of the movie, Leah was my *person*. My best friend. We did everything together. We were inseparable. We had our own language, our own inside jokes, our own world. We were total weirdos, and we didn't care who knew it.

But then I got pregnant. And everything changed.

At first, she was supportive. She helped me tell my parents, she went with me to the doctor, she tried to be there for me. But then… she started to pull away.

I think she was scared. Scared of what it meant for our friendship. Scared of what it meant for me. Scared of the future.

She didn't know how to deal with it. And instead of talking to me about it, she just… shut down. She started hanging out with other people, she stopped returning my calls, she just… distanced herself.

I tried to fix it. I tried to talk to her, to explain how I was feeling. But she wasn't willing to listen. She was too caught up in her own life, her own plans.

And then, when I decided to give the baby up for adoption, she was… disappointed. She thought I should have kept it. She thought I was making the wrong decision.

It was like she didn't even understand me anymore.

We had a huge fight. We said some really hurtful things to each other. And then… we just stopped talking.

Towards the end of the movie, we start to reconnect. She comes to the arcade with me and Paulie. It's awkward, and we don't really talk about what happened. But it's a start.

It wasn't a perfect reconciliation. We weren't suddenly back to being best friends. But we started to understand each other a little bit better. We started to accept each other for who we are.

It evolved from this incredibly close, all-consuming friendship to something… more mature. Something more realistic. It wasn't the same, but it was still important.

It showed me that friendships can change. That people can grow apart. And that sometimes, the best thing you can do is to let go. But it also showed me that even when friendships are strained, they can still be salvaged. It just takes time, and effort, and a willingness to forgive.

So yeah. That's how our friendship evolved. It was messy, and painful, and complicated. But it was also real. And it taught me a lot about myself, and about the importance of communication and understanding. And honestly, it still hurts to think about it sometimes. But I'm glad we found a way to move forward. Even if it's not the way I expected.

(A long pause. A surprised little huff.)

Okay, wow. That's… not a question I expected. And honestly? It's a hard one. There weren't a lot of parts I *loved*. It was… a lot.

But if I had to pick something… it was feeling the little kicks.

Seriously. It sounds cheesy, I know. Like something out of a movie. But it was amazing.

At first, it was just little flutters, like butterflies in my stomach. And then, as the months went on, the kicks got stronger and more frequent.

It was a reminder that there was a tiny human being inside me. A little person who was growing and developing and getting ready to come into the world.

It was a really powerful feeling. A feeling of connection. A feeling of responsibility.

And it was also kind of funny. Sometimes the baby would kick me really hard, right in the ribs. And I'd have to laugh.

It was a weird and wonderful experience. And it's something I'll never forget.

It wasn't about *wanting* to be pregnant. It was about acknowledging the life inside me, and feeling a connection to it. And those little kicks… they were a reminder that even in the midst of chaos, there was something beautiful happening.

So yeah. The kicks. That was my favorite part. It was a little bit magical. And it was a little bit terrifying. But it was definitely something special. And honestly, it's something I miss, a little bit. Don't tell anyone I said that.
